definition:
[*Gelfond’s constant*]{} $e^\pi$ was one of the first numbers to be
proven to be transcendental by appying Gelfond’s theorem. However,
naming the constant after Gelfond comes from Eric Weisstein, with many
people preferring to refer to it simply as $e$ to the power of $\pi$.

Its value in base 10 is approximately
23.1406926327792690057290863679485473802661062426. Its continued
fraction representation is neither terminating nor periodic, and begins
$$23 + \frac{1}{7 + \frac{1}{9 + \frac{1}{3 + \, \cdots}}}$$
